Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Dynamics of Knowledge and Capital Flows in East Asia

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to data constraints the final nature of the project diverged away from the original plan to compare Singapore and China's Knowledge Capital Flows. In responding to the concerns of the review panel, I focused on innovation in Chinese manufacturing and how this was driven by foreign investment and export participation.

To do this, I spent a summer in Singapore working with economics faculty who had extensive experience with Chinese innovation and foreign investment.

My main research findings indicate that export promotion policies did more to stimulate innovation in Chinese manufacturing - significantly more than foreign investment. I define innovation to be the fraction of firm output (by value) that is a new product. This information was in the data set I used. Approximately 27% of the firms in my sample are exporters, and 11% have capital from foreign sources.

I try to estimate how this index of innovation changes as firms transition into (and out of) exporter status. I repeat the tests for changes in the foreign-ownership status. Given that Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) has been the traditional means of explaining innovation in China, I use FDI as the baseline, and compare the outcomes with that of changes to export status. To reduce bias from firm selection into FDI or export status, I estimate the aforementioned effects using matching techniques, i.e. I compare innovation outcomes for firms with roughly the same predicted propensity to export (or receive foreign investment). The 'treatment effect' is the difference between the firm that actually experienced the export (or foreign investment) transition, and the one that did not, but which makes a good counterfactual because its observable characteristics are similar to the first.


These results suggest further inquiry into the processes that drive foreign investment and export participation in East Asia, as well as their consequences for firm competition, learning and efficiency.


Last Modified: 06/02/2011
Modified by: Michael-Adetayo Olabisi
